evidence.dc:description: HINT1 is ubiquitously expressed in mice and humans, however it does have a significant presence in the central nervous system of mice particularly in the olfactory sensory system, cerebral cortex, hippocampus, part of the thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata (PMID: 18270824). GAPDH staining in adult mouse tissues confirmed significant expression in the sciatic nerve, supporting its role as a vital component of the peripheral nervous system as well.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Inherited peripheral neuropathies are frequent neuromuscular disorders known for their clinical and genetic heterogeneity. In 33 families, we identified 8 mutations in HINT1 (encoding histidine triad nucleotide-binding protein 1) by combining linkage analyses with next-generation sequencing and subsequent cohort screening of affected individuals. Our study provides evidence that loss of functional HINT1 protein results in a distinct phenotype of autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia.
dc:source.dc:creator: Zimoń M
dc:source.dc:title: Loss-of-function mutations in HINT1 cause axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia.

evidence.rdfs:label: HINT1 CNS Expression

evidence.dc:description: HINT1's expression in the CNS and sciatic nerve support the protein's role in a primary motor neuropathy.

The membrane and nuclear proteins targeted by HINT1 are essential for proper synaptic tonus and gene transcription regulation. Specifically, Teneurin1 has been implicated in processes such as neurite growth, axon guidance, and synaptogenesis. Without the proper ability to desumoylate proteins via activation of isopeptidase activity, this could certainly be related to the observed motor and sensory neuropathy phenotypes and the neuromyotonia.

dc:source.dc:creator: Cortés-Montero E
dc:source.dc:title: The Axonal Motor Neuropathy-Related HINT1 Protein Is a Zinc- and Calmodulin-Regulated Cysteine SUMO Protease.

evidence.rdfs:label: HINT1 Sumolayse Activity

evidence.dc:description: HINT1's function as an essential signalling protein via isopeptidase activity in the CNS and peripheral nervous system supports both the primary motor neuropathy and neuromyotonia present in the majority of probands.

HINT1 interactions with various proteins was tested with almost all known pathogenic variants and the WT. In an interaction with SUMO1, R37P and G93D behaved as the WT and G89V increased the association, while the other mutants reduced the level of interaction. When interacting with CaM, mutants C38R and those in the 84-89 region increased the association with the others showing reduced interactions. The evaluation between HINT1 and the NR1 subunit of the glutamate NMDA receptor demonstrated increased association with G38V and G89V, but diminished interactions for all other human HINT1 mutants. Binding to the MOR c-terminal cytosolic tail showed the same pattern, with only G89V not displaying a reduced interaction. RGSZ2, which normally forms stable complexes with HINT1 and MOR, showed a disparate pattern of strengthening or weakening the association with the mutants. Finally, interactions were reduced with ICD Teneurin 1 for all except the 84-89 region and all but C38R and G89V displayed very weak interaction with σ1R. All of these interactions are normally observed at the plasma membrane, with disruption substaintially altering the HINT1-regulated signalling pathways in human probands.

Further supporting evidence is provided in PMID: 29787766. This publication uses a subset of the variants utilized here and further confirms the structural alteration of mutant HINT1, specifically that R37P, G93D, and W123* exist as monomers rather than forming dimers like the WT. Both the mutant monomers and dimers also suffered from impaired thermal stability compared to the WT. The catalytic activity of the homodimers were comparable to the WT, but all monomers tested showed significantly reduced hydrolysis activity. These futher support the inability of mutant HINT1 to interact with signalling proteins properly.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The 14 kDa histidine triad nucleotide-binding protein 1 (HINT1) is critical to maintain the normal function of motor neurons. Thus, a series of human HINT1 mutants cause autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia. HINT1 establishes a series of regulatory interactions with signaling proteins, some of which are enriched in motor neurons, such as the type 1 sigma receptor or intracellular domain (ICD) of transmembrane teneurin 1, both of which are also implicated in motor disturbances. In a previous study, we reported the capacity of HINT1 to remove the small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) from a series of substrates and the influence of HINT1 mutants on this activity. We now report how human HINT1 mutations affect the interaction of HINT1 with the regulator of its SUMOylase activity, calcium-activated calmodulin, and its substrate SUMO. Moreover, HINT1 mutants exhibited anomalous interactions with G protein coupled receptors, such as the mu-opioid, and with glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors as well. Additionally, these HINT1 mutants showed impaired associations with transcriptional regulators such as the regulator of G protein signaling Z2 protein and the cleaved N-terminal ICD of teneurin 1. Thus, the altered enzymatic activity of human HINT1 mutants and their anomalous interactions with partner proteins may disrupt signaling pathways essential to the normal function of human motor neurons.
dc:source.dc:creator: Cortés-Montero E
dc:source.dc:title: Human HINT1 Mutant Proteins that Cause Axonal Motor Neuropathy Exhibit Anomalous Interactions with Partner Proteins.

evidence.rdfs:label: HINT1 Mutant Protein Interactions

evidence.dc:description: These functional studies demonstrate significant alterations in the mutant's function compared to the WT protein. Multiple abnormalities, including signalling protein interaction, the ability to dimerize, and hydrolysis activity, are present when testing all known human pathogenic variants. Due to the strength of evidence and the breadth of variants tested, this evidence is upscored to 1 point.

evidence.detectionMethod: SNP genotyping was performed on this family. Parametric linkage and fine mapping yielded a single autosomal region candidate on chromosome 5. Exome sequencing revealed a homozygous missense variant that segregated with disease.
evidence.rdfs:label: ZI_CMT1380P

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous missense w/ variant-level evidence (Mutants failed to rescue HINT1-deficient yeast compared to WT; lack of protein expression confirmed)

evidence.detectionMethod: 262 individuals with AR and sporadic CMT were screened via direct sequencing in HINT1. This proband was found to have a homozygous null variant.
evidence.rdfs:label: ZI

evidence.detectionMethod: A custom panel and the Ion Torrent NGS platform analyzed 33 genes associated with these axonal sensorimotor neuropathies (AARS, DNM2, GJB1, IGHMBP2, MFN2, RAB7A, TRPV4, ATP7A, DYNC1H1, HINT1, KIF1B, MPZ, REEP1, VAPB, BSCL2, HSPB1, LMNA, NEFL, SETX, YARS, DCTN1, GARS, HSPB3, LRSAM1, PDK3, SLC5A7, DHTKD1, GDAP1, HSPB8, MED25, PLEKHG5, and TFG). A homozygous indel mutation was found and confirmed via Sanger sequencing. Direct sequencing of the parents and sister showed heterozygosity for the variant.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: At 12 years had undergone bilateral tendon transfer and calcaneal osteotomy to improve gait with little benefit; DNA testing excluded PMP22 duplication; See Table 1 for nerve conduction study results

dc:source.dc:creator: Boaretto F
dc:source.dc:title: Novel loss-of-function mutation of the HINT1 gene in a patient with distal motor axonal neuropathy without neuromyotonia.

evidence.rdfs:label: BO

evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from blood and exome sequencing was performed and aligned. SNP databases were excluded with filtering applied to detect all novel variants in each patient. Genotyping experiments were performed to validate candidate variants. Heterozygous carrier status was confirmed in the parents.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Most patients had already undergone genetic testing for some of the genes involved in dHMN and were negative for SMN1 variants; Sural SNAP amplitude 20 uV; EDB CMAP amplitude 2.8 mV

dc:source.dc:abstract: Distal hereditary motor neuropathies (dHMNs) are a heterogenous group of genetic disorders with length-dependent degeneration of motor axons. Obtaining a genetic diagnosis in patients with dHMN remains challenging. We performed exome sequencing in a diagnostic setting in 12 patients with a clinical diagnosis of dHMN. Potential disease-causing variants in genes associated with dHMN and other forms of inherited neuropathies/motor neuron diseases were validated using Sequenom. The coverage in the genes studied was >95% with an average coverage of >50 times. In none of the patients a mutations was found in genes previously reported to be associated with dHMN. However, in 2/12 patients a recessive mutation in histidine triad nucleotide binding protein 1 (HINT1, recently discovered as a cause of axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia) was identified. Our results demonstrate the diagnostic value of exome sequencing for patients with inherited neuropathies. The phenotypic spectrum of recessive mutations in HINT1 includes dHMN. HINT1 should be added to the list of genes to check for in dHMN.
dc:source.dc:creator: Zhao H
dc:source.dc:title: Exome sequencing reveals HINT1 mutations as a cause of distal hereditary motor neuropathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: ZH_dHMN4

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous missense w/ variant-level evidence (PMID: 29787766 shows altered structure and interactions with signalling proteins)

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole genome SNP genotyping was performed on this family. Homozygosity mapping revealed no large regions, suggesting compound heterozygosity. Parametric linkage and haplotype analysis yielded three potential regions not containing any known CMT genes. WGS of two affected siblings revelaed 32,725 variations that were filtered to two heterozygous variants in HINT1. Sanger sequencing confirmed segregation with all affected individuals.
evidence.rdfs:label: ZI_CMT68P

evidence.dc:description: Compound heterozygous missense variants w/ variant-level evidence (Mutants failed to rescue HINT1-deficient yeast compared to WT; lack of protein expression confirmed).

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted and next generation sequencing used to identify HINT1 mutations and sanger sequencing to confirm them. Segregation analysis was performed on the parents.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia (ARANNM) is a rare disease caused by mutations of histidine triad nucleotide binding protein 1 (HINT1) gene. ARANNM has been reported mainly in European countries but little reported so far in China. We describe novel mutations of HINT1 in three Chinese patients with ARANNM from unrelated families. Patient 1 was a 14-year-old girl who presented with progressive distal weakness of upper limbs at two years of age. After that, she reported weakness of both feet, and difficulty in muscle relaxation after making a fist. Patient 2 was an 18-year-old boy, who presented with progressive distal weakness of all limbs with foot drop at the age of ten with loss of ambulation at age 15. Patient 3 was a 26-year-old man who had been afflicted with weakness and atrophy of distal lower limbs since the age of 16 complaining about muscle stiffness of the lower limbs when standing and walking, and contraction of finger flexion muscles when releasing a forced grip. Electrodiagnostic testing revealed an axonal motor or sensorimotor neuropathy with or without myokymic discharges. Sural biopsy showed no pathological changes in patient 1 and mild axonal neuropathies with demyelination in patients 2 and 3. Genetic analysis revealed HINT1 with novel compound heterozygous c.112T > C (p.C38R) and c.171G > C (p.K57N) mutations in patient 1, homozygous c.112T > C (p.C38R) mutation in patient 2, as well as compound heterozygous c.112T > C (p.C38R) and c.98T > C (p.F33S) mutations in patient 3. Our study, for the first time, confirms ARANNM in the Chinese population. These genetic findings can help expand the genotypic spectrum of HINT1 mutations.
dc:source.dc:creator: Meng L
dc:source.dc:title: Novel mutations in HINT1 gene cause autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia in two cases of sensorimotor neuropathy and one case of motor neuropathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: ME3

evidence.dc:description: Compound heterozygous missense variants w/o variant-level evidence

evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from peripheral blood or saliva. All three exons and exon/intron boundaries of the HINT1 gene were PCR-amplified and sequenced. Available family members were tested to prove segregations in the family.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previously tested genes were CMT1A, GDAP1, LMNA, and Cx32; Nerve conduction velocity results in Table 2

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in the HINT1 gene were recently discovered as being the major cause of autosomal recessive axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia. This combination was clinically recognized and described previously in a few reports but is generally unknown. We aimed to establish the importance of HINT1 mutations as the cause of hereditary neuropathy and particularly hereditary motor neuropathy/axonal Charcot-Marie-Tooth (HMN/CMT2) among Czech patients. Overall, mutations in the HINT1 gene seem to be a surprisingly frequent cause of inherited neuropathy in our group of patients. Biallelic pathogenic mutations were found in 21 patients from 19 families. The prevalent mutation in the Czech population is the p.R37P (95% of pathogenic alleles). Clinically, all patients with biallelic mutations presented with early onset of symptoms at the end of the first decade. Foot/toe extension weakness to plegia was present in almost all patients. Neuromyotonia was present in all but two patients. However, it had been properly recognized in only three patients prior to molecular genetic diagnosis. HINT1 mutations seem to be one of the most frequent causes of inherited neuropathy and are probably the most frequent cause of HMN in Czech patients. We suggest all HMN/CMT2 patients be tested for the presence of the prevalent mutation, the p.R37P.
dc:source.dc:creator: Laššuthová P
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in HINT1 are one of the most frequent causes of hereditary neuropathy among Czech patients and neuromyotonia is rather an underdiagnosed symptom.

evidence.rdfs:label: LA6-I

evidence.dc:description: One premature termination variant and one heterozygous missense w/ variant-level evidence (PMID:22961002; Arg37Pro shows inability to rescue deficient yeast and lack of proper expression)

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted and next generation sequencing used to identify HINT1 mutations and sanger sequencing to confirm them. Segregation analysis was performed on the parents.
evidence.rdfs:label: ME1

evidence.dc:description: Compound heterozygous missense variants w/o variant-level evidence

evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from blood and exome sequencing was performed and aligned. SNP databases were excluded with filtering applied to detect all novel variants in each patient. Genotyping experiments were performed to validate candidate variants. Heterozygous carrier status was confirmed in the parents.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Most patients had already undergone genetic testing for some of the genes involved in dHMN and were negative for SMN1 variants; Sural SNAP amplitude 38 uV
evidence.rdfs:label: ZH_dHMN11

evidence.dc:description: Two missense variants w/ variant-level evidence (PMID: 29787766 shows altered structure and interactions with signalling proteins)

evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted and next generation sequencing used to identify HINT1 mutations and sanger sequencing to confirm them. Segregation analysis was performed on the parents.
evidence.rdfs:label: ME2

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous missense variant w/o variant-level evidence

dc:description:
HINT1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in 2012, characterized as an axonal neuropathy with neuromyotonia (Zimon et al., PMID: 22961002). Although neuromyotonia was initially defined as a core feature of the disorder, reports of probands without neuromyotonia indicated incomplete penetrance for this phenotype. At least twelve unique variants (e.g. missense, nonsense, frameshift, etc.) have been reported in humans, with the most common pathogenic variant c.110G>C (p.Arg37Pro) being a founder variant observed mainly in patients of Slavic origin (PMID: 31848916). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data.
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least ten probands in five publications (PMIDs: 26059562, 24105373, 25342199, 30001929, 22961002) and segregated with disease in four additional family members. These probands generally present with a primary axonal neuropathy characterized by gait impairment, progressive distal muscle weakness and atrophy, facial/foot deformities, and neuromyotonia. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism for disease is biallelic loss of function, as the mutant proteins are unable to fulfill HINT1's signalling role in the central and peripheral nervous system (PMID: 33404983).
This gene-disease association is supported by expression evidence, HINT1's biochemical function in the nervous system, and a series of functional studies performed on pathogenic variants in cell and animal models. Primary expression in the CNS and PNS indicates the crucial role that the protein fulfills, while loss of the sumolayse activity that HINT1 provides matches with the primary motor neuropathy phenotypes observed in probands (PMID: 31088288). Additionally, functional evaluation of all known pathogenic variants demonstrated a variety of altered functions including impaired thermal stability, disrupted dimer formation, and loss of interaction with SUMO1, CaM, and ICD Teneurin 1 (PMID: 33404983).
In summary, HINT1 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.
